awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Draining the landscape: Will the drop in stream and groundwater levels following dam removal increase the leaching/leakage of nitrogen (N) from riparian zones?
awd_abstract_narration:
A large number of dams are currently being removed across the U.S. and at an accelerating pace. Most of the dam removals are driven by the need to increase public safety, reduce owner liability, and improve fish/aquatic habitat. However, little attention is being paid to how dam removals could influence water quality. Generally, dams slow down the flow of water and simultaneously raise the level of water in the stream and in the stream-side areas known as riparian areas. Unintentionally, this provides a valuable benefit: wet soils rich in carbon act as important filters for nitrogen, a key pollutant in waterways. This natural filtering service reduces stream water nitrogen concentrations and improves water quality. Dam removals could undermine this valuable service and potentially increase nitrogen in streams. This study will quantify how dam removal alters the capacity of riparian soils in filtering nitrogen. Results will be conveyed to landowners and natural resource agencies which will position them to make informed decisions on dam removals and better manage our watersheds. The study will provide a valuable opportunity for education and professional development for undergraduate and graduate students. In addition to presentations at professional conferences and meetings, project results will be disseminated to broader, non-academic audiences through talks at community Science Cafes.

Near-surface groundwater and wet soil conditions in riparian zones, particularly upstream of dams, enhance denitrification in soils - a key mechanism by which riparian zones filter and remove nitrogen (N) from soils and act as hot spots for nitrogen buffering. Dam removals can lower groundwater levels, expose and dry riparian soils, and result in loss of valuable denitrification ecosystem services. Furthermore, drying of soils could enhance mineralization and nitrification, processes that release soil N and increase water pollution.  This could result in riparian zones switching from watershed N sinks to sources. This hypothesis (increasing soil N leakage following dam removal) will be tested at the Chickies Creek site in Pennsylvania where the Krady Mill dam was recently removed. Stream water and ground waters at two riparian transects will be monitored and sampled weekly to study changes in concentration of nitrogen species. Riparian soil samples along the transects and at various soil depths will be collected to measure changes in soil N concentrations and the rates of mineralization, nitrification and denitrification. Measured process rates along with areal extent of the drained soils will be used to estimate/predict the N leakage (kg per unit stream length) following dam removal. Considering increasing dam removals across the U.S., results from this study will provide novel insights critical for watershed management and assessing the benefits and drawbacks of dam removal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Starting in the 1700s, hundreds to thousands of milldams were constructed by early European settlers in the US for running mills using water power. Milldams existed every few miles on streams in the eastern US, particularly in the mid-Atlantic region. Most of these milldams have since breached or have been removed. The remaining milldams are now increasingly being removed by natural resource agencies and state and local governments for enhancing public safety and fish habitat in streams.  Little however, is known about how milldam removals impact water quality. 

Milldams raise stream and riparian groundwater levels upstream of the dam.  Riparian zones have been found to be effective in removing excess nitrogen (N) from groundwater when water levels are high and near the soil surface. This N removal happens via processes like plant uptake and denitrification and therefore riparian zones are considered as ?buffers? for N pollution. We hypothesized that milldam removals would lower the stream and groundwater levels and thus undercut valuable N removal services like denitrification and plant uptake resulting in increased N concentrations in riparian groundwater and streams.  In addition, well-drained soils have also been shown to increase N through the process of nitrification.  Hence, we hypothesized that nitrification would increase while denitrification would decrease in riparian soils following dam removal.

We evaluated these hypotheses for the Krady dam removal on Chiques Creek near Columbia, Pennsylvania. The dam which was originally built in the 1700s was 1.5 m tall and 30 m wide, was removed on July 9, 2018.  Stream and groundwater levels dropped by 1.5 m after dam removal. Our groundwater and stream water sampling started November 2018, after the funding of this grant, and has continued to date providing about two years of data.  Our results suggest that while soil water concentrations of nitrate-N in the drained soils were elevated, riparian groundwater nitrate-N concentrations were low and there has been no perceptible increase in nitrate-N for the past two years.  Similarly, while stream water N showed distinct seasonal variations in N, there has been no long-term trend of increasing or decreasing N in stream waters.  Similarly, riparian soils did not display any increasing or decreasing trends in denitrification or nitrification rates for the past two years. Thus, the data did not support our primary hypotheses. We speculate that while nitrate-N was likely being leached from the surficial riparian soils, the denitrification rates in groundwater (now lower than before dam removal) were still sufficiently elevated to remove any excess nitrate-N generation.

To our knowledge, this was the first study that has investigated how milldam removals could impact riparian groundwater N. Our results suggest that riparian soils or zones are resilient and can buffer any sudden changes in groundwater levels associated with milldam removals. This data provides important information that could help watershed agencies and managers make more informed decisions with regard to dam removals.  It should be noted though that sampling started four months after dam removal and we did not have any pre-removal data (because of lack of information on the exact date of dam removal and lack of funding to initiate a study). Our study is also currently limited to only two years and thus the longer term changes in soil and water quality are unknown. In addition, the height of the Krady dam was relatively small ? only 1.5 m. We do not know if the results and conclusions from this study would extend to taller dams. Additional studies are recommended that investigate taller milldam removals and which include pre-dam removal conditions and continued monitoring beyond two years after dam removal.
